The main aim of the project Do the (r) evolution! is to develop high quality activities for young people in the fields of art, youth and civil engagement with the help of informal and nonformal learning. Encouraging critical thinking towards the existing power relations in the world , understanding differences in globalised world , taking responsibility of your actions,  developing your own ideas, and to be able to plan and execute your ideas , are key components of our projects. The project will last for 11 months and give them the possibility to participate in the formation of cultural, youth, youth-information, volunteer and social activities of Pekarna Magdalenske mreže. Three volunteers, a 24 year old girl from UK, , a 24 year old boy from Spain and 24 year boy from Spain, will be actively involved in the EVS project, and through that have the opportunities to achieve personal growth and acquire a sense of belonging to the organization and local community. 

Volunteers will be involved in: 
- Pekarna DOBIŠ DAŠ, activities with and for children and young people with less opportunities;
- Footsteps of the city, urban walks and discussions about the city and the engaged use of public space;
- Guest Room Maribor, artists in residence platform;
- Aunt Rosa's Library, library with a critically engaged literature;
- Gallery K18, gallery open to young artists;
- Pekarna potopisi, travelogues with a critical note;
- Program for helping refugees.

Both volunteers will be strongly encourage to develop their own project ideas in the field of photography and civil engagement.

Goals/intentions of the project Do the (r) evolution! are following:
1. To provide room for gaining key competences such as: communication in a foreign language, learning to learn, interpersonal, intercultural and social competences, cultural expression.
2. To empower the EVS volunteer to work in creative and socially critical processes (active participation and active citizenship).
3. To establish room for learning for young people through mutual transfer of knowledge and skills between EVS volunteer and other coworkers and young people within the organization.
4. To direct, reflect and evaluate the gained knowledge and skills, to achieve volunteer’s knowledge of them.
5. To develop intercultural and interpersonal understanding among young people in local environment.
6. To establish basic conditions to increase autonomy of young people and raise possibilities for their employment.
7. To establish and strengthen quality international partnerships (between organizations).
8. To enable professional development of youth workers, who are included in the project, and therefore to enable professionalization of youth work.
9. To support civil society organizations in the field of youth by developing quality projects with long term effects in the local environments of sending and hosting organizations.

Expected effects and results of the project are following:
- to strengthen the role of youth workers,
- to empower volunteers towards increased participation in society (also in the field of non-conventional political participation),
- to increase recognition of EVS among young people in our organization and among young people in the local environment,
- to establish quality international partnerships,
- to upgrade existing and gain new key competences in both volunteers,
- increased sensibilty of the local enviroment/community in accepting the differences among cultures etc.

Long term effects are following:
- increased professionalization of youth work in our organization,
- established quality of hosting and sending environments to carry out programs of mobility in partner organizations,
- to prevent and overcome prejudices in hosting and sending environment,
- to prevent social exclusion of young people,
- a raised interest of young people in the local community in the mobility programmes.

Methodology:
- weekly meetings with EVS coordinator,
- monthly meetings with EVS mentor,
- weekly meetings with the team (coworkers),
- monthly reports from volunteers,
- interim and final evaluation of the project with volunteers and the organization,
- lessons of Slovene language (2 hours per week),
- organized team work,
- individual work,
- education,
- workshops.

Historically, young people have faced social exclusion, and the recent economic downturn has prompted high unemployment, which particularly affects the younger generation. However, some disadvantaged groups of young people face exclusion in the longer term for reasons beyond the current crisis. Remaining outside the global labor market has far-reaching consequences – not solely economic. These include a loss of confidence, an undermining of trust and expectations, and an increasing risk of social exclusion and disengagement from society. 

Apart from the economical crisis there are other issues and dangers that affect youth generation and lead to political crisis. Global threats such as terroristic attacks and armed conflicts caused a huge refugee and migration wave in Europe. These and many other factors stipulate increasing of intolerance, xenophobia, violence, conflicts oriented by cultural fears, numerous stereotypes and prejudices, intercultural misunderstanding, inability to think critically and lack of intercultural competence in general. Young people are more than others affected by those issues, especially being in a situation of current economic crisis.  They feel afraid, they are frustrated, they don’t know what to feel and how to react, as a result they became either inactive or join the extremist movements, and they definitely need to be supported in this hard situation by adults, by peers, by educational institution, by NGOs and by policy makers.

Tackling youth unemployment, social exclusion, intercultural communication and youth participation continues to be a policy priority for European and national governments, but the need to empower young people are increasingly recognized in this process.  We see youth empowerment as an attitudinal, structural, and cultural process whereby young people gain the ability, authority, and agency to make decisions and implement change in their own lives and the lives of other people, including youth and adults. In other words empowered young people will exercising power over one’s life by being skilled, critically aware, and active in creating community change.
The long-term training course “InFormal part II” it is an integration of non-formal education approach to the formal education system for youth empowerment at local level” is an attempt to use non-formal education as a tool for youth empowerment, in order to address the all mentioned issues and to build a stable and productive co-working platform for educators coming from formal education and youth field (NGOs and other youth authorities).  
This training course will be the second edition of InFormal project, involving more partners struggling with the mentioned issues at local level and will aim to unite the efforts for increasing youth participation and active citizenship through introducing non-formal education approach to the formal schooling where young people spent most of their time.
Long –term training course objectives:
- To unite efforts of youth workers coming from formal and other youth field backgrounds for youth empowerment at local level by using non-formal education
- To build a necessary set of competences for proficient use of non-formal education instruments and tools for youth empowerment at local level
- To introduce the values, principles of non-formal educations
- To discuss the recognition of competences gained by non-formal education 
- To provide the possibility to plan, experiment and to get feedback to the non-formal education activities
- To discuss and introduces the ways of integration of non-formal education activities to the system of formal education
- To provide the opportunity to assess the quality of non-formal education activities and youth empowerment process at local level
- To build a network and to create joined actions in order to address current challenges
This training course is especially contributing to promoting synergies, cooperation and cross-fertilization between the educational institutions and youth field as well as to the following specific objectives of Erasmus+ Youth:
• improve the level of key competences and skills, with particular regard to their relevance for the labor market and their contribution to a cohesive society, in particular, through increased opportunities for learning mobility and through strengthened cooperation between the world of education and training and the world of work
• foster quality improvements, innovation excellence and internationalization at the level of education and training institutions, in particular through enhanced transnational cooperation between education and training providers and other stakeholders; 
As a general outcome, we expect our participants to improve their competences in non-formal education and in the topic of youth empowerment, as well as other competences linked to their professional profile; for broader understanding of non-formal education, as the most effective tool for youth empowerment
Boys' and Girls' Clubs of Wales

Activists against Xenocide invites 30 professionals of non- formal education to a training and 44 participants to a youth meeting (among them 36 young  people  between 15 and 19 years old) from DE, PL, EE, UK, MK, RS and GR to learn about the reasons, conditions and consequences of migration and fleeing today and in the past. Participants are encouraged to take part in an intercultural exchange and discuss during  workshops, seminars and film-photo training political and historical experiences as well as knowledge of migration. Individual stories of people are in the center of attention. Furthermore, professionals demonstrate media skills which lead to higher qualification and enable young people to work in this area and prepare them for the upcoming youth exchange in their local communities. Through the project participants address questions such as how can we humanly deal with the refugee situation, what do refugees actualy experience, including the situation of the participant’s home countries (solidarity and discrimination) and how they can actively act and advocate for people in need. Based on the impact on Europe's societies we will closely examine, the process of European integration and the way of dealing with today’s migration and refugee situation in Europe. Apart from dominating narratives about refugees and migration today and in the past, that exist in the general European public, participants deal with personal stories of people who have undergone that fate and share their individual experiences. During a methodological workshop (film and photography) youth workers will be enabled to work on this topic with young people in their local communities. They deal with the current need for standing up against violation of human rights and become active. With the help of film and photography, participants analyze the situation of migrants in their local community. During the youth exchange, the collected material will be analyzed, edited and prepared for public presentations, to be held in the local communities of the participants. Thinking of a group structure we will take into account cultural and social diversity, in order to have a realistic image of European societies and to ensure the multi-perspective approach to the subject of fleeing and migration.

Meeting Point Saxony IX is a project being held  from November 2017 to October 2018 in Dresden and the region of Saxony, which involves volunteers in various projects, activities and events organised by Jugend- & Kulturprojekt e.V. Two volunteers have the opportunity to learn and develop their skills in the areas of Event, Cultural & Project Management,  Youth Work, Non-formal education, Social media and digital media - Graphic and Web Design, Photography & Filming research and administrative work. Active citizenship and European awareness are promoted through the active participation of the volunteers in multilateral EU projects in the field of arts and culture, youth participation, urban development, creativity, entrepreneurship, remembrance, EU values and human rights. By involving volunteers from different countries, cultural backgrounds and age groups, cultural diversity is promoted and equal opportunities are provided. 

The young people who are selected are expected to volunteer for a period of 12 months. Thus volunteers have the opportunity to integrate to the local community of Dresden and learn the German language and culture. The volunteers work and live in a multicultural environment and have the opportunity to develop their soft and hard skills through non-formal learning methods such as experiential and peer-learning, workshops, cultural events, reflection meetings and discussions, mentoring, collaborative work, research, audiovisual presentations and excursions. The volunteers who participate in the "Meeting Point Saxony IX" project should have a keen interest in digital and social media, arts, youth work as well as project, cultural and event management. The volunteers should be accepting different cultures, religions and beliefs,  should have understanding, and should be willing to learn and share their knowledge with other volunteers and young people involved in JKPeV's projects. In addition, the volunteers should enjoy being and working in a multicultural environment and respect all colleagues and staff. The volunteers should be interested in developing projects which contribute to the society and the urban development. Young people with fewer opportunities are given priority. 

Non-formal learning methods are used throughout the EVS project, such as experiential learning, self-directed and peer learning, research work, collaborative work and workshops. The volunteers are always supported by an experienced mentor who is responsible for guiding and assisting the volunteers in personal and social issues. The project coordinators give the volunteers daily tasks and provide them assistance and consultancy.  

The volunteers are expected to develop their skills and competences, they learn to work and live in a multicultural environment, respect different cultures, religions and beliefs; learn to work in a team and to be aware of EU values. "Meeting Point Saxony IX" aims to motivate young people to be active EU citizens and contribute to the development of the society. Be engaging international volunteers in local activities, JKPeV seeks to promote international cooperation between Dresden, its surrounding areas and other countries so that the local community is more open to international partnerships and more tolerant and accepting towards different cultures and influences. 

Through "Meeting Point Saxony IX"  more people learn about the Erasmus+ programme and the opportunities which provides to young people and young people with fewer opportunities. Therefore EU dimension and active participation in international projects are promoted.

he internet has changed the types and possibilities of human interaction. The internet has given us the possibility, in theory, to communicate with almost any other person in the world; it has even made it possible, in theory, for one thought in a back room in a small and unknown corner of the world to be picked up by every other person! Everyone with access to the internet is now both publisher and public speaker. Few, it seems, can interfere with what we want to say. This is a novelty that few would want reversed, but it should not surprise us that the ever-expanding world of online interaction has also come to reflect and feed back into many of the difficulties that human beings have historically encountered in their ‘real’ existence. Intolerance and ‘hate’ have been a feature of human society almost since time began. A number of studies have identify an increase in these attitudes over recent years. The problem is that if there is less tolerance of differences, and if the constraints on that intolerance are not watched, then intolerance – and hate – will find expression, both in the things that people do and in the things they say. The internet has opened up new ways of saying things, and it has opened up new avenues to say them to more people. The constraints, however, on what we can say online are far fewer than those which exist off-line: we can say things over the Internet that we would not dare to say in public in the ‘real’ world. If hate speech offline is a problem that societies have recognised, and found the need to address, is online hate speech something that we can ignore? Of course not.
Young people are already suffering from online hate speech:
 • Across Europe, 6% of 9 to 16-year-old Internet users reported having been bullied online, and 3% confessed to having bullied others.
• 16% of young Internet users in Europe say they have posted comments on the Internet that were hateful towards a person or group of people.
 • 78% of the respondents of an online survey stated they had encountered hate speech online on a regular basis. The three most recurrent targets of hate speech were: LGBT people (70%), Muslims including refugees and migrants of Muslim origin (60%) and women.
The problem is huge, and it becomes bigger and bigger especially in nowadays when we all face economic  breakdown and unemployment as result, huge refugee wave, raise of extremism and terrorism etc. All those challenges contributes to spreading hate speech online, as young people are in the situation of ambiguity and frustration.
In 2012, Advisory Council on Youth of Council of Europe started the No Hate Speech Movement, the campaign that aimed to combat the hate speech online in all its forms, and with this “No hate” project we want to contribute to making internet a safer place for young people and to prevent human rights violation online.
The issues that will be addressed by competences developed during the project are:
• Decrease the level of aggression and intolerance online through civil society organisations/youth workers.
• Perception of phenomena of hate speech and its influence on young people's lives.
• Subjective opinion, memory and bias.
• Human rights online
• Peace-building
• Internet literacy
• Freedom of speech
• Promoting intercultural dialogue
• Preventing radicalization of young people
A project “No hate” is a long-term project aiming at combating  with the hate speech online and to promote no hate speech movement among young people, if approved it will consist of  TC and YE:
The first activity, a training course will be run in Armenia, 9-17 September 2016 This will be TC for youth workers teachers and trainers aiming to equip them with knowledge and skills on how to tackle the topic of hate speech with young people through non-formal education.
The second activity (youth exchange) will be run in Luxembourg on 7-16 December 2017 That will be a youth exchange on internet literacy, that will involve not just young people but also bloggers and online activists. After this exchange, we expect our group to start the online campaign “Be the change: make internet safe for everybody”.

The main objective of the project „Labyrinth in the Head” is to equip youth workers with Sensory Labyrinth Theatre (SLT) method, which helps them in their every day work with the youth to address personal- and local-level challenges associated with refugees/ migrants and to disseminate the European common values, especially connection to common humanity and compassion. 

6 organisations from 5 European countries, who are partners in this project, have pointed out intolerance towards refugees in their home countries. 

On the local (community) level people tend to express intolerance through hate speech and hate acts. There have been reports about vandalism in refugee centres in the very beginning they were established. Several neo-nazi groupings have got wind under their wings and right-wing parties have got more supporters. 

On personal level a lot of local people believe that refugees represent a threat to host countries, that there is a lot of terrorists among refugees, that they want to spread islam and steal jobs from the local. In addition local people are afraid of losing their own identity, nationality, culture, religion, jobs etc. 

We believe that the core of the problem lies in dehumanization of refugees, dividing people into „us” and „them”. What is needed most by both refugees and people living in countries who host them is a sense of connectedness: a connection to common humanity. In our opinion, drama methods are best to reach this goal.

SLT provides this connectedness for those who engage with it. From this connection to common humanity, which transcends cultural and even linguistic differences, compassion emerges naturally. SLT harnesses this emerging compassion and supports participants to channel it in useful ways to support and guide each other through uncertain and precarious times.

18 youth workers from 5 European countries will meet on 25.09.-04.10.2017 in Tartu, Estonia in a training to learn SLT methods. 8 days long training includes morning and afternoon SLT workshops lead by creator of SLT method, Iwan Brioc, evaluation sessions in the end of every day, SLT performances in the end of the training to try out and share the results of the training, socializing time etc. All this serves the aim to equip the participating youth workers with competence and methods for addressing personal- and local level challenges associated with refugees.

To deepen understanding of refugees' situation every group prepares a research of the current refugees crisis as a homework – what are the main personal- and local-level challenges associated with refugees in their countries. The researches are presented in the beginning of the training session. During training Skype interview with Syrian refugees in Turkey and a meeting with refugees in Estonia take place to provoke intercultural dialogue and search for similarities in differences. 

During this training the youth workers have chance to experience the method themselves through exercises. Then they work in groups and create for each other improvisational sensory journeys. Also they can try the method out with the adults. After acquiring the essence of the method they create sensory portals and form a structure of the SLT production for the youth. They learn to use and tune this method on a very specific topic - refugees, which is very relevant in nowadays' world. 

After the training 18 youth workers are ready to use SLT in their every day youth work. To test it partner organisations will arrange 4-6 dissemination events after the training course. So the participants/ participating organisations can try out their competence to use SLT as a method to address personal- and local-level challenges associated with refugees, share their multi-pointed overview of the current refugee crisis and disseminate European common values. 

Capacity to use SLT methods in addressing personal- and local-level challenges associated with refugees/ migrants or other socially sensitive topics will be available in youth work field of 6 different countries. Youth workers will use the method of SLT or parts of it (games, exercises) in their daily work with the youth and in community.

The local communities and Europe as a whole becomes more tolerant. Disseminating the project results supports the resistance to the hate speech and intolerance and hopefully prevent violent radicalisation of several young people.

(People in the roles of) refugees/ migrants will find more understanding and help in hosting societies. They will have better opportunities to get involved and integrated into hosting societies. Hosting communities and countries will act more smoothly. Europe as a whole will become again a bit more tolerant. People will acknowledge a little bit more common humanity and compassion in themselves.

The project widens its impact through Timo Mikkola's thesis on how to use SLT method in approaching refugee topic, which will be available on web.
European Youth Work in South Wales

“European Youth Work in Wales” will provide a mobility activity for 8 volunteers from Spain, Belgium, France, Poland, Russia and Austria. The volunteers will be based in South Wales, and will be engaged in various different kinds of youth works with clubs and schools in the area. The projects will focus on themes such as cultural awareness, non-formal learning, community cohesion, land mangament, ICT and youth work.  All the projects will engage with young people in the South Wales area with a focus on promoting promoting diveristy and intercultural understanding. 

The activities (EVS) will be long term (11 months) to allow the volunteers’ time to really get involved with the Youth Centre & schools and the work that they do, as well as having the opportunity to develop their own personal projects. Through non-formal and informal learning methods the volunteers will increase their knowledge and experience in international youth work. The project will allow young people from Europe to interact, share ideas, exchange cultures and learn about each other in a safe and supportive environment.  The volunteers will be fully integrated into the activities of the hosting organisation and will be given the opportunities to focus on elements that most interest them and to develop new skills, experiences and knowledge that will enhance their employability and personal professional development.

Volunteers will be encouraged to bring ideas and opinions from their countries of residence to the UK to share with each other, to break down international barriers, as well as take new ideas back to input into their society, thereby creating a wider European Community.

Alongside their project work, the volunteers will also attend common days each month where they can share their experiences and participate in workshops and training focusing on diversity, racism, xenophobia, migration and active citizenship. Through the common day activities, the volunteers shall obtain tools and knowledge that they then bring back into the communities they are volunteering in to actively promote diversity and create more welcoming and open minded communities in South Wales.  This will promote active citizenship and will help to foster engagement in the local community whilst bringing to light both global and local issues.

Through Intercultural Dialogue to Better Chances for Employment

The overall aim of the project is strengthening of the intercultural competences through methods of non-formal education as a tool to increase the participants’ employment opportunities to gain new knowledge and skills which will provide them with better chances for future employment. Additionally it will promote intercultural dialogue as an advantage in their community – to learn and to accept working in intercultural environment facing its challenges and benefits. 

The main objectives of this youth exchange are:
- to provide capacity building to marginalized youth for better employment opportunities through an intercultural dimension
- to strengthen intercultural competences through non-formal education as a tool to increase better employment opportunities
- to promote equity and inclusion in the employment process through intercultural dialogue
- to raise awareness of the importance of the intercultural dialogue in the work environment
- to explore different competences required for employment
- to develop soft and social skills of young people

The project will gather 4 young people and 1 youth leader per country from 6 different countries (Poland, Spain, Turkey, Macedonia, Italy, UK), 30 participants in total. They will gather in Ohrid, Macedonia 10-17 July 2017 where they will develop their employment competences. 

The outcome will be a small guide with tips and tricks on how to write a CV and motivational letter that will be  prepared by young people themselves. Moreover, the guide will be accompanied with a compilation of small videos serving as witnessing of what they have learned, what challenges they have faced and how they have been able to meet them.

Freedom of  expression is of crucial importance for Europe, being it currently shaping its whole history. In fact, the media is more biased and untrustworthy that ever. For a bright and democratic future young people need to be able to express themselves in an honest manner. This project has been created by young people (mainly editors of the online magazine 'Are You Lost Yet') to help give young people that opportunity.

'Are You Lost Yet' is two 9 day youth exchanges funded by the Eramus+ youth mobility programme on developing young peoples personal development and competence using online magazines, especially those from marginalized, vulnerable and underprivileged backgrounds. It will be held in Kumanovo, Macedonia and Cardiff, Wales, UK and bring together two different partners from distinct different countries; 20 participants will take part support by 4 staff / team members. The youth exchanges will use non-formal methods and activities to help participants connect the use of creative online journalism with inter-cultural learning, breaking down barriers to inclusion, experiential learning, development of critical thinking, developing teamwork and citizenship. The participants will take part in a huge amount of experiential learning themselves through the use of different activities such as research, design, investigative journalism, art, etc..    

The main focus of the youth exchanges will be developing an online magazine as a learning tool and form of self development. The educational programme will aim to develop young peoples abilities to use online journalism, artistic pursuits and creativity as a learning tool, formally, informally and non-formally as well as a method of pushing their comfort levels and developing their confidence. Using these methods to raise awareness about youth issues, human separation from the natural world and explore the possibilities to act toward sustainable culture as well as tools for breaking cultural, social and geographical barriers. 

By exchanging their own experiences on this project, participants will get first-hand practice in inter-cultural learning. We believe that “AYLY” will be a fun and effective way to achieve understanding for the cultural diversity in Europe by sharing personal cultural backgrounds in sustainable culture, youth experience and attitudes towards global issues. The impact however will not be limited to the Inter-cultural learning process only but also it will provide basic knowledge for using this method as an education tool for a variety of subject areas such as self employment and entrepreneurship, development of critical thinking, journalistic skills, use of digital and online materials, etc. We will be working together towards through teamwork to create 3 online magazines for each NGO that will be published for young people across Europe and the Globe. It will present the competencies, improvements and skills the diverse group has developed as well as be a positive example for the use of digital, online and creative media in youth work. Displaying how the group managed to use teamwork, experience, creativity and as well as initiative to not only create interesting and innovative ideas, but to develop new skills, experience and a unique story. The recommendations will be designed in form of check list for freedom of expression, youth activities for personal development, user friendliness and sustainability that young people feel strongly about.

The project itself is conceived by young volunteer's Tom Bevan, Marc Tilley and a number of his peers in support of; and to compliment their online creative space www.areyoulostyet.com which is under the wing of Project 2020. The project is completely youth driven and lead. The project aims to support the professional development and employability of young learners from the project through involving them in structured learning processes in all nations in cooperation with all organizations from the mobilities. In addition, the project is also aimed at strengthening the support structure for young learners from the UK and Macedonia through involving professional youth workers in shadowing experiences in the involved organizations. In other words, the project combines staff and learner activities in order to provide a structured and comprehensive learning process for learners in the chosen areas. 

This project will include activities of practical and non-formal educational training for learners and staff from the United Kingdom, which will be implemented in Wales, UK, and Macedonia. The activities hosted in Wales will be in the field of entrepreneurship and management of media projects, while the ones in Macedonia  will be focused on entrepreneurship in the field of creativity and artistic development. 

The receiving organization from UK will host an exchange for 4 youth workers and for 20 young people. The organization from Macedonia will host the same.

The project is youth led.

In a European society where the concern for the reconnection of education with the labor market is increasingly present the "Volunteers action for Community" proposes an innovative perspective on learning: the sports and outdoor experimental solutions aimed at developing entrepreneurial skills and overcoming barriers in the relationship with others coming from different backgrounds and cultures. 

-Activity no 1-2-3: a group EVS stage (lasting 8 months, held in the city of Arad in Romania and city of Cardiff, UK , Poggiardo/İtalya) to who will take part 12 young people from TR (of which at least 4 with fewer opportunities) . Activity no 4: By 8 youth workers participation to the activities which will have been held in Cardiff / UK, planning of upcoming terms will be developed, and our leaders, trainers, disadvantaged participants and participants with fewer opportunities will be trained about the experiences and its local capacity through increasing the capacity of our partner. Besides, trainers inside our team will share and introduce our country, cuture and youth work capacity to other participants. The experiences and knowledge our youth worker will have achieved in this mobility will contribute us, as sending organization, to create/establish healthier/more sustainable proccesses for the youngsters who are willing to be a part of EVS programme.   


Objectives: 
- in what concerns the young participants in mobility: developing entrepreneurial skills, initiative and ability to perform as active citizens and participate effectively in European intercultural dialogue. Moreover, we estimate that these young people will develop key skills in inter-personal communication. 
- In what concerns the youth workers participating to mobility : developing specific skills required by youth worker professional career and acquire greater confidence in their abilities. 

Our project will involve at least 100 children and young people in the city of Arad / Ro, Poggiardo/İt and Cardiff / UK as members of local target groups in the community where the EVS volunteers stage will take place . These are mostly facing economic & social barriers (including those belonging to roma ethno-cultural) . We estimate the project as related to target groups, using methods / techniques / experimental approaches will help to develop the capacity for social integration and positive relationship / fair-play with others, in the spirit of European values and intercultural dialogue. Mai much these children & young people in the target group will develop interpersonal communication skills and language skills. 
-in what concerns the 12 young people from TR participants in EVS mobility: developing entrepreneurial skills, initiative and ability to perform as active citizens and participate effectively in intercultural European dialogue. Furthermore, these young people will develop inter-personal communication and business key skills, and the ability to adapt to new environments much different from home. 

The main expected results of the project: 
- learning outcomes generated among young people and youth workers.

Young Europeans improving skills in Community Supported Agriculture

“Young Europeans improving skills in Community Supported Agriculture” will be an EVS project for 3 volunteers from France, Hungary and Spain. The volunteers will be based on a farm near St. Davids, Pembrokeshire, West Wales and another one in Parkmill on the Gower close to Swansea and they will be engaged in a variety of activities based in COCA and Cae Tan, two community supported agriculture schemes. The project will focus on themes such as cultural awareness healthy lifestyle, organic community supported agriculture and intercultural learning. 

The individual activities will be long term to allow the volunteers time to really get involved with their organisation and the work that they do, as well as having the opportunity to develop their own personal projects. The projects will allow young people from across Europe to interact, share ideas, exchange cultures and learn about each other in a safe and supportive environment.  The volunteers will be fully integrated into the activities of their hosting organisation and will be given the opportunities to focus on elements that most interest them and to develop new skills, experiences and knowledge that will enhance their employability and personal professional development.

Volunteers will be involved in activities such as;  community growing, digital media work, Events support/ organisation, leadership opportunities, training support/ attendance, promotions, community development, as well as having the opportunity to bring in their own ideas and work on personal projects where appropriate.

This project will promote active citizenship and will help to foster engagement in the local community whilst bringing to light both global and local issues. Volunteers will be encouraged to bring ideas and opinions from their countries of residence to the UK to share with others, to break down international barriers, as well as take new ideas back to input into their society, thereby creating a wider European Community.
Horn Development Association Community Interest Company HDA

Traditional methods of monitoring and evaluation of impact are not fully appropriate to be implemented on the ground, due to lack of knowledge or understanding of M&E among non-specialist implementers, not always capable of identifying both intended and unintended outcomes of the intervention, not participatory or inclusive enough. 
The project aim is supported by the following specific objectives to be reached:
1. Developing the capacity of 28 youth workers from 13 organizations from United Kingdom, Turkey, Romania, Hungary,  Slovenia, Spain, Croatia, Check Republic, Estonia, Poland, Bulgaria and Portugal to adapt and use creative and participatory methods for monitoring and evaluation of impact for effective design and implementation of learning activities for young people and innovative dissemination of results, in 11 months. 
2. Enhance the effective participatory monitoring and evaluation of impact for at least 1 learning activity for youth in each of the 13 partner organization over a 2 months period following the mobility.
3. Supporting the exchange of experience and good practices in the field of innovative dissemination of the creative and participatory methods of monitoring and evaluation for impact in youth work, among the 28 youth workers from the 13 partner organizations, in 11 months.
The following activities will be done in order to reach these objectives:
Step 1 - A1: Training course (June 4-10, 2018 in Estonia) for 28 youth workers from 13 partner organisations from 12 countries. The topic of the training program is creative and participatory methods for monitoring and evaluation for impact assessment or learning activities in the youth field. The training program agenda encompasses 7 working days.
Step 2. Piloting of minimum 13 methods back home in the period of 4 months after the mobility (at least one of the methods acquired during the training in one of their learning activities/org.). Each partner, supported by the trainers, will have to organise at least one learning activity with approx. 10 young people to use at least one of methods on M&E impact assessment learned in the TC. 
Step 3. The Seminar (August 6-12, 2018, in Cardiff, Wales, UK) for sharing good practice and lessons learned during the pilot activities and dissemination activities initiated already. It will be aimed at supporting the exchange of good practices developed and tested by the participants in the period in between the 2 mobilities and facilitate the creation of project ideas that will further build on the acquired knowledge and skills. 
Step 4. Developing an online tool “dissemination game” that has as major purpose to motivate the participants to reach as many stakeholders as possible and use the game to “level up” their experience in dissemination. We will use in the game various ways of doing dissemination and exploitation of results and they will have to choose and try to do as many as possible (at least half) in order to go to the next level and win the game by the end of the project. Such ways could include: organisational websites; meetings and visits to key stakeholders; information sessions, workshops, (online) seminars, training courses, exhibitions, demonstrations, or peer reviews; targeted written material such as reports, articles in specialised press, newsletters, press releases, leaflets or brochures; audio visual media and products; social media; public events; existing contacts and networks, Salto toolbox, Erasmus+ Project Results Platform etc. 
During the activities different non-formal and informal methods will be used to support the exchange of know-how between participants. Methodology used will include creative and participatory techniques for M&E and will result from the trainers and participants experience and input.
For the participants, besides the importance of certifying their acquired competences through European instruments, these is a very important process for the them because, by being involved directly in it, they will understand even better the importance of applying in their work diverse, innovative and personalized monitoring and evaluation tools in order to have an objective assessment of the impact obtained in learning activities. Thus they will be able to use and transfer this model in their work and help their youth produce real instruments for validating acquired competences. Also they will increase their IT skills in using on-line tools.

GIC NORA has defined further strengthening and development of international cooperation as one of the priorities in its long-term strategy.

The aim of this project is the mutual transfer of expertise and personal experience between GIC NORA and volunteers particularly in the area of gender equality. The project should also contribute to the strengthening of important labor competencies, not just for both volunteers, but also for members of GIC NORA. Last but not least, the project should establish long-term international cooperation due to volunteers and partner organizations.

The project will involve two volunteers whose profiles are:

A1 - The participant completed secondary education and has experience in working with aging people. Participant was chosen because of her interest to become more familiar with the issue of promoting equal opportunities. The participant comes from Italy.

A2 - The participant is an university student with focuse on human rights and equal treatment. She was chosen  due to her knowledge of our key interest and motivation to participate in the implementation of the international project Towards Gender Sensitive Education. The volunteer comes from Scotland.

Both volunteers will acquire expertise in gender equality and gender equality tools (eg Gender Audit) by participating in the project. They also acquire or reinforce many key competencies in the labor market (eg Time management, project management, search and information skills, bargaining skills, independent work, communication skills, organizational skills, teamwork). After completing the European Voluntary Service volunteers will be able to apply the experience, knowledge and competencies in their next occupation.

Through its implementation, GIC NORA will strengthen its international cooperation, improve the language skills of its members and their intercultural sensitivity, and improve its profile and image.

ADICE specializes in youth mobility and coordinating French and European mobility projects for more than 15 years. Our expertise  through all these projects has been strengthened over the years and we have developped high quality tools (mobility passport, skills booklet...) to support better all participants in their project.

The goal of ADICE, and of the project, is to ensure the social and professional development of the learners (including those with fewer opportunities), by participating in a valuable mobility experience. ADICE considers the mobility experience as a tool allowing the development of technical, transverse and social skills which favors employment. 

The project “LUCIE: Learning Unique Competencies In Europe” plans for two years, from the 1st of June 2017, the sending of 30 learners in vocational training, in mobility for purposes of learning, in the eligible countries of the European Union, planned in our partnership agreement: in United Kingdom, Italy, Ireland, Portugal, Germany, Spain and Czech Republic. These mobility projects will be characterized by professional internships in companies or within non for profit organizations, and would last for 3, 6 or 10 months.

These placements will be organized and defined according to the experience, sector of activity, professional project, needs, expectations at short and long term and the profile of the participants. Indeed, ADICE’s goal is to promote the European mobility, but also to fight against discriminations and to promote people with fewer opportunities at a social and professional level. Our public is diverse and so, our projects are, first of all, accessible to all local learners, without any discrimination, yet no level of studies is required or limited age, and also, characterized by destinations, durations, and various sectors of activity. They are fitted to the needs, objectives and profile of each person. Participants are supported with regard to all these criteria and on the motivation and relevance of the participant’s personal and professional project. 

At the level of the European partners, we work on one hand with intermediate structures which organize the mobility of the participants, and, thus, provide a support to the participants with more difficulties, and on the other hand, we work also more and more directly with host structures and companies. These structures are found, during the whole contract period, and especially selected for the mobility of a participant in specific areas. They also may have already hosted participant within their structure in past projects.
Our partnership network is related to our internalization strategy. It is characterized by a geographical, linguistic and economic diversity a plurality of activities sectors adapted to every public (social, tourism, sale, communication, etc.) and of types of structures (companies, associations, training centers…) Every partner, whether it is a direct structure or intermediate structure, is in charge of providing a quality placement (within its structure or one of its local partners), if possible the accommodation, and a support if the participant is facing difficulties (in the activities, with the team, social or cultural difficulties, or a problem linked to the security of the participant). Indeed, the partner has to provide a quality follow-up during the mobility, and a relevant and fitted evaluation at the end. The diversity of the partners allows us to offer a large panel of relevant opportunities to the participants’ needs and careers. Thus, our international strategy aims at offering internships in companies as well as in associations, in a varied number of professional sectors and in a diversity of countries.

Regarding the development at the European level, ADICE being a territorial actor of social and professional inclusion, our action plan is in complete relevance with the analysis of the needs at the territorial and sectorial level, but also for the public. Indeed, the Hauts-de-France area is very affected by unemployment, which rate is higher than other area and largely exceeding the national rate (12%, while 9.6% in metropolitan France data given by INSEE for the 2nd trimester 2016). Moreover, the city of Roubaix knows a high economic development, but the rate of unemployment stays high and affects 30.9% of the local population. 
With mobility experience being an entrance to employment, it enables the development of new experiences, skills and opportunities to enrich the professional life, the project of ADICE is thus absolutely relevant at a local level, according to the territory priorities and background. Moreover, a project like this one, allows the development of the territory at a European level, the enlargement of the opportunities and network and the exchange and developpement of new skills among this local network, which is a real added value for our structure but also for the territory.
